problem: Let $n$ be a positive integer greater than or equal to $3$. Let $a,b$ be integers such that $ab$ is invertible modulo $n$ and $(ab)^{-1}\equiv 2\pmod n$. Given $a+b$ is invertible, what is the remainder when $(a+b)^{-1}(a^{-1}+b^{-1})$ is divided by $n$?
solution:
We can use the fact that $x\cdot x^{-1}\equiv 1\pmod n$ for all invertible $x$ in the following clever way: \begin{align*}
& (a+b)^{-1}(a^{-1}+b^{-1})\\
\equiv~ & (a+b)^{-1}(a^{-1}+b^{-1})(ab)(ab)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (a+b)^{-1}(a^{-1}ab+abb^{-1})(ab)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (a+b)^{-1}(a+b)(ab)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (ab)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & \boxed{2}\pmod n
\end{align*}
